Chapter 6: Distinguishing the Path Truth, Distinguishing the Path Truth. The sÅ«tra says, What is the path truth?
What is the basis for this statement?
If the path can extinguish craving, then it should not be said that practice leads to the end of suffering.
If it is not so, then this statement contradicts itself.
If both the arising of suffering and the end of suffering are extinguished, why is it not fully explained in the sÅ«tra?
If the path can end suffering, then one who has accomplished the practice of the path should have no remaining suffering.
If it is not so, then it should not be said that practice leads to the end of suffering.
If conditioned dharmas do not lead to the unconditioned, then how can it be said that practice leads to the end of suffering? The meaning of right practice.
Right practice refers to the eightfold noble path. What is the use of definitively speaking of the noble? What is the meaning of noble?
Why is it said that only the path is called noble, and not the other factors that assist the path?
If the path is different, then its characteristics should be explained.
If it is said that the path is only a part, then there is no difference between the whole and the part. What is the meaning of the term path?
How is it that this sÅ«tra speaks of the whole, while other sÅ«tras do not?
If the path is conditioned, how can the Buddha say that it existed in the past?
If it is unconditioned, how can it be said to be conditioned?
If the path is one, then when one person cultivates it, others should attain it, just as with clothing, etc.;
If it is not so, then it should not be said that it is by this one path.
If all sages attain the same one path, how can their wisdom be different?
If their wisdom is different, how can their liberation be equal?
If the path is not mind, then insentient things should also have the path.
If the mind is not a mental factor, then cultivation is incomplete;
If it is a mental factor, then how can mutually contradictory dharmas exist simultaneously in one mind?
If the path leads to the removal of delusions, then mutually contradictory dharmas exist simultaneously in one mind;ğŸ”½...
If it does not reach, how can it eliminate in the continuum of others?
If the parts arise together, there would be many intentions. If they arise in sequence, there would only be one part. Why are only eight parts established, neither more nor less?
Why not take other dharmas such as desire?
How can one dharma be explained in three ways?
The middle way can eliminate good and evil practices to the end of suffering. Why is right view said to be the beginning?
Why is it said that right view should be practiced first? What is the meaning?
If there is no seer, who is the one who sees?
How is right view different from the right view of the ten wholesome paths?
If the truths are seen at one time by right view, there should be many objects;
if not, then they are not momentary.
If the truths are already understood by right view, what is the use of the other parts?
What is the meaning of right understanding?
How are the three dharmas made into one?
If one attains the extinction of defilements based on the second concentration, one lacks perfect enlightenment and lacks the factors of the path. This meaning should be saved.
What is the meaning of right?
If there is speech, the path is cultivated without concentration.
Why is this?
The Buddha said that concentration is a thorn of sound.
If there is no non-attainment, it does not become a factor of the path. What is the meaning of right action?
All factors are right action. Why is only one called right action?
If apart from the name right action, apart from it is not making, how can it become action?
Apart from beating and hitting, etc., why is it not called a factor of the path?
How are right action and right livelihood different from the ten wholesome actions, right action, and right livelihood?
What is the meaning of right livelihood?
If right livelihood is included in bodily and verbal actions, why is it established separately?
What is right effort?
What are its characteristics, functions, objects, and meanings?
If only the cessation of evil is good, then there is no second effort;
If it is not good, then the truth of cessation is not good.
If one who cultivates right effort is already perfect, then there are no four right efforts.
If one cultivates in sequence, then the cultivation of the auxiliary path is not complete.
What is right mindfulness?
What are its characteristics, functions, objects, and meaning?
Since conditioned phenomena do not abide for a moment, how can they be remembered?
Why is this?
Because it is not possible for one to see and remember what another sees and remembers.
If all dharmas are mindfulness foundations, and the faculty of mindfulness is itself a mindfulness foundation, then the meaning is not appropriate.
If mindfulness itself cannot guard a single dharma, how can the sÅ«tras speak of having mindfulness and guarding one thing?
How is it that sometimes one can remember and sometimes one cannot?
What is samÄdhi?
What are its characteristics, functions, objects, and meaning?
If right concentration is concentration, then a stream-enterer should have no desire or anger;
if it is not so, then it contradicts reason.
You ask, How is the path truth explained in the sutras?
What is the basis for this statement?
The answer:
This question is not for the sake of enlightening people.
Why is it so?
Because the meaning is already understood upon hearing the name.

Arising from great compassion, it explains the path to nirvana, revealing the hidden meaning. Wishing to extensively explain the lamp, it is for the sake of distinguishing the disciples of wisdom. Therefore, the Buddha himself asks.
Why is it so?
Because there is much benefit in first asking and then explaining.
The extensive explanation of dependent origination has already been explained above.

Moreover, the disciples who receive the teaching ask the non-Buddhists, Hearing various paths, I am not yet able to determine which is the correct path and which is the wrong path. In order to eliminate doubts, delusions, ignorance, and other wrong thoughts, the Buddha himself asks and answers.
What is the path?
It is the eightfold noble path, like a guide leading people on the right path when they are doubtful about the road.
You ask, If the path can extinguish craving, then it should not be said that practice leads to the end of suffering;
If it were not so, this statement would be contradictory.
Answer:

From the initial arousal of the mind, the sages cultivate in order to eliminate suffering.ğŸ”½In order to do this, they give rise to the path, and therefore it is said that practice leads to the end of suffering.
The end of suffering is accomplished by the cessation of its causes, just as with a lion.
Moreover, the Buddhas observe that all sentient beings fall into suffering and difficulty, arouse the mind, cultivate the path, and eliminate the suffering of others.
This cultivation is like what is said in the Sutra of the Parable of the Country.
Moreover, another sutra says:
The end of suffering is the function of leaving the home and practicing the holy life, as in the Sutra of the Parable of the Seven Chariots.
Moreover, the Tathagata appears in the world for three reasons. Causing others to end their suffering is the foremost, and therefore it is said that practice leads to the end of suffering.

Moreover, all conditioned things are suffering because they are impermanent. Therefore, in order to be apart from conditioned things, it is said that suffering ends, as in the Sutra of the Parable of the Raft, which says:
Even the Dharma should be abandoned, let alone what is not the Dharma.
Furthermore, since the eightfold noble path can eliminate the aggregates grasped at, therefore, the two cessations are mentioned together without contradiction.
You ask, if the cessation of suffering and the cessation of the origin are the same, why is it not fully explained in the sutras?
The answer:
The cessation of craving is manifested by the exhaustion of suffering.
Furthermore, the exhaustion of causes is not the main point, the exhaustion of suffering is the main point.
Furthermore, since the noble path can eliminate conditioned phenomena and the aggregates grasped at, the exhaustion of suffering is mentioned together with the cessation of craving.
You ask, if the path can exhaust suffering, then those who have accomplished the practice of the path should have no suffering of the three realms;
if not, then it should not be said that one reaches the exhaustion of suffering by practicing.
The answer:

The exhaustion of suffering is said to be due to the exhaustion of causes, just as the exhaustion of a fire is called the exhaustion of its ashes, and just as the destruction of the roots is said to be the destruction of the tree.

Furthermore, the noble path can extinguish the suffering of wrong discrimination, but not the suffering of karmic retribution from past actions, nor the suffering of realms and stages. For example, like the Ká¹£atriya Candala and UpÄsaka.
Furthermore, the noble path can extinguish the suffering of the mind in the nirvana with remainder, and can extinguish the suffering of the body in the nirvana without remainder.

Furthermore, the noble path can extinguish the suffering of the aggregates in future existences, but the suffering caused by past actions still follows and has not been extinguished, like a wheel and an arrow.
You ask, if conditioned dharmas do not reach the unconditioned, how can it be said that one reaches the end of suffering?
The answer:

Nirvana has no path of practice, nor does it have practice. Although both do not reach nirvana by returning to it, because it enables one to attain nirvana, it is said that one reaches the end of suffering. For example, like a national road.
Furthermore, this is an expression of skillful means, like saying that all flowing things sink in the water and flow to the end.
The flow and water drops are without activity in the midst of exhaustion, yet the world speaks of activity. Going to the end of suffering is also like this.
You ask, what is the meaning of right practice?
Answer:
Because of this understanding of the true meaning, it is called right practice.
Moreover, advancing is called practice, as it is said to practice in all places.
Moreover, being able to go to a place of peace and security is called right practice.
Furthermore, right means not turning away, and practice means returning to. Because of this, not turning away and returning to nirvana, it is called right practice.
You ask, the right practitioner is the eightfold noble path. What is the use of this definitive statement?
Answer:
It is to counteract other paths, to establish practice in all places, and to show not going to other places.

Furthermore, it can exhaust all the suffering of the path, it can block all the burning heat of afflictions, karma, and retribution, it can remove the fear of bad words, heavy punishment, and death in the evil realms of oneself and others, it can remove the accumulated bones like Mount Vipula, and it can dry up the milk, blood, and tears. For this reason, it is said with certainty.
You ask, what is the meaning of the term noble?
The answer:
Because the essence is undefiled, of one taste, and liberates sentient beings, relying on this continuum, one is called a noble person, just like good dharmas.
As it is said in the sutra:
This is the noble right view.

Furthermore, because it is practiced by noble people, it is called noble, just like a king's road.ğŸ”½Furthermore, because it is spoken by noble people, it is called noble, just like a teacher's path.
Furthermore, because it is attended to by the noble assembly, it is called noble, just like a cow path.
Furthermore, because it causes one to reach the ultimate nobility, it is called noble, just like a national road.
As it is said in the sutra:
Noble right liberation.
You ask, why is it only called the noble path and not the other aids to the path?
The answer:
Because they have the same characteristic, they are all called noble, like the nature of fire.
Moreover, because they have the same taste of liberation, like the salty taste of seawater.
Moreover, the eightfold path is foremost and can include the other aids to the path, as explained in the Elephant's Footprint Simile Sutra.
You ask, if the path is different, its characteristics should be explained.
If it is said that the path is only a part, then there is no difference between the whole and the part.
The answer:
The characteristics of the difference between the whole and the part can also be seen and explained, like the five-part samÄdhi.
It is also like the bhiká¹£us with five parts abiding in the five parts, and the path is also like this.
There is a difference between the whole and the part, and the equality of the part is called the path.
Why is it so?
When these eight factors reach the state of equilibrium, they can eliminate afflictions. If they are sunken or agitated, they cannot eliminate afflictions, just like tuning a string.
Moreover, these factors are said to be the path because they can accomplish the goal, like a chariot.
However, if we speak from the perspective of true reality, the factors are complete, like a five-part musical ensemble or the five-part samÄdhi.
The path is also like this, with only the factors being the path.
The treatise now states that only the factors are the path, with six proofs.
First, it is said in the sÅ«tra:
The five faculties are the path, leading to nirvÄá¹‡a.
Since these five faculties are the factors of the path, we know that only the factors are the path.
Second, the sÅ«tra says that the three bodies encompass the path, and the three bodies are only the factors.
Third, due to cessation, the sÅ«tra says:
Right view leads to cessation. Apart from the path, there is no cessation.
Fourth, due to elimination, the sÅ«tra says:
If one cultivates right view, it can eliminate desire and so forth. If one is apart from the path, then one cannot eliminate [desire and so forth].
Fifth, by means of liberation. The sutra says:
The various factors such as right view can liberate from this. If it is not the path, then it cannot liberate.
Sixth, by means of the pure path. The sutra says:
PrajÃ±Ä is the path, for the sake of attaining purity.
PrajÃ±Ä is right view. Therefore, we know that the factors are the path.
You ask, what is the meaning of the term path?
The answer:
The path has the meaning of seeking and investigating.
Why is it so?
Because by this one can attain the true meaning, and also because it has the meaning of action.
As for it also has the meaning of action, it is like the worldly saying:
This path goes to ÅšrÄvastÄ«.
The path is also like this, returning to nirvÄá¹‡a.
Moreover, the principle of the gate of true meaning and the principle of expedient practice, these are all the meaning of the path.
You ask, why does this sutra speak of the complete factors, while other sutras do not?
Answer:
The Dharma Treasury Treatise says:
There are two kinds of provisional names: one is autonomous provisional names, and the other is dependent provisional names.
The names of the constituents of one's own body are autonomous provisional names, like the factors of the path such as right view.
The dependent provisional names are like the gates of mindfulness and the other auxiliary factors of the path.
Why is it so?
The cultivation of this path is not scattered cultivation.
Moreover, it is because one factor is predominant among the mindfulness, etc.

Among the mindfulness, etc., one factor is predominant, and the others are given the same name, like the tastes of salt, sour, etc., which have other tastes but are named according to the predominant one.
It is also like the various realms, which are named according to the predominance of one factor.
Moreover, in the desire realm, the factors of the path are explained.

In the form and formless realms, there are either five or four, because they eliminate the four counteragents of one's own body, and the rest may increase or decrease according to the realms and stages.
For this reason, there are those who possess it and those who do not.
You ask, if the path is conditioned, how can the Buddha say it is the ancient path;
if it is unconditioned, how can he also say it is a conditioned dharma?
The answer:
Because of this ancient saying, the path is conditioned.
Why is it so?
Because conditioned dharmas have novelty and decay, like grains and so forth.
If it were unconditioned, it should not be called this, like space and nirvana.

Just as it is said that the body is the result of past karma and is not unconditioned, like the holy lineages and the various masters of the Dharma. Therefore, because of this ancient saying, the path is not unconditioned.
The path that is now being discussed is conditioned.
How do we know this?
Because it is extensively distinguished.
Like the Sutra on the Characteristics of the Truths and the answers to questions from DharmadinnÄ.
Because of the characteristics of the conditioned, as the sutra says:
Relying on right contemplation, if the path has not yet arisen it can be made to arise, and if it has already arisen it can be made to increase and flourish.
Because it has arising and growth, we know it is conditioned.
Because it is abandoned, as a sutra says:
Dharmas should still be abandoned, let alone non-dharmas.
If cessation were unconditioned, it could not be abandoned.
Because it arises internally, as a sutra says:
This path arises internally, this refuge is difficult to attain.
If it were unconditioned, it would not arise internally.
Because of the name of action, as a sutra says:
This path is neither black nor white action, it can extinguish all actions.
If it were action, it would not be an unconditioned dharma.
Because it has nutriment, as a sutra says:
The seven factors of enlightenment have nutriment as their cause.
If it were unconditioned, it would not need nutriment as its cause. For this reason, the path is conditioned.
You ask, if the path is one and a person cultivates it, others should attain it, just as with clothing, etc.;
if it is not so, then it should not be said that by this one path.
The answer:
Many paths are not one.
Why is this?
Because the fruits are not the same.
Because the paths are different, the fruits are different, just as the paths are different because the travelers are different.

Moreover, the paths are different because the natures are different, referring to the path of seeing, the path of cultivation, and so forth, also like the four kinds of suffering, pleasure, slow, and fast.

Moreover, the paths are different because the faculties are different, referring to the nine learners, the nine non-learners, the pratyekabuddhas, and the buddhas, because of the differences in faculties, there are differences.
Based on the spiritual lineage, it is said there is one path, just as the world speaks of one grain, as the sutra says:
The buddhas of the three times, whether contemplating or teaching, contemplate and teach these four truths. The three truths of suffering and so forth are actually impermanent.
The statement about one path is also like this.
You ask, if the noble ones attain the same one path, why are their wisdoms not the same?
If their wisdoms are not the same, why is their liberation equal?
The answer is:
Observing all phenomena of all kinds, one attains perfect enlightenment. Therefore, the Buddha's path is not the same as the two vehicles.
As a sutra says:
If a person knows all phenomena of all kinds, know that this person is called the World-Honored One, because he has realized the path of equality.
Only the extinction of the fundamental afflictions by the people of the three vehicles, as a sutra says:

Liberation from the five aggregates is no different from liberation. Just as many fires each burn firewood until the ashes are extinguished, but there is no difference. It is due to the difference in the fires' heat, light, and majestic virtue.

In the same way, the difference in wisdom and the afflictions extinguished are the same in liberation. Therefore, the majestic virtue and grace of the Buddha's definite wisdom are difficult to fathom due to the differences in the path.
As the MahÄcakra SÅ«tra says.
You ask, if the path is not a mental factor, then insentient things should also have the path.
If the mind is not a mental factor, cultivation is not complete.
If it is a mental factor, how can mutually contradictory dharmas exist together in one mind?
Answer:
The mind is a part of birth and death, a worldly dharma, while the path is a supramundane dharma, and the two are not mutually corresponding.
Because it is like dharma and non-dharma, it is said that the path is not a mental factor.
The mind is named based on the object, while the path is sought based on the ability. If the two were one substance, then the self-nature would know itself;
In order to avoid this fault, it is said that the path is not a mental factor.
It is like life, the attainment of non-perception, and the attainment of non-thought, etc. Although they are not mental factors, they do not exist in walls, etc. The path is also like this.
Although the path has the mind, it is not in the position of the mind. Because it reaches everywhere, there is nothing that is not cultivated.
Moreover, there are three kinds of cultivation, namely guarding, practicing, and investigating, so there is nothing that is not complete.
However, the path can also be said to be a mental factor.
Why is it so?
Because it is born and extinguished together with right thought, it is like one mind.
As the sutra says:
Because the mind becomes dominant, one attains single-mindedness, which is called mental concentration, which is a part of the path.
Because they have the same goal and accomplish the same thing, they have the same single-mindedness and are not in conflict.
You ask, if the path reaches and eliminates afflictions, then conflicting dharmas would exist simultaneously in single-mindedness;
if it does not reach, how can it eliminate them in the continuum of another?
The answer:
The path does not reach the afflictions but is able to eliminate them.
Just as the path does not reach the precepts but is able to eliminate one's own transgressions of the precepts and not others' transgressions of the precepts, so it is with eliminating afflictions.
Although it does not reach both one's own and others' continuums, it only eliminates one's own afflictions and cannot eliminate others' afflictions.
The VibhajyavÄdins say:
It is neither reached nor not reached, and at that time it eliminates afflictions, because non-arising is taken as cessation.
It is like treating an illness. When painful feelings have already arisen, the doctor cannot treat them.
Why is this?
Because it is impossible to transform suffering into happiness.
Suffering that has not yet arisen, even a doctor cannot cure.
Why is this?
Because it does not yet exist.
If so, what is it to be cured of?
It only acts as an adverse condition, preventing the suffering that has not yet arisen from ever being able to arise.
The path that removes afflictions is also like this.
You ask, if the parts arise together, then there would be many mental activities, but if they arise in sequence, then there would only be one part.
The answer:

Because they accomplish one thing, they are able to arise together. It is not because they take different objects, so there is no mixing of many mental activities arising together. The differences can be seen due to their functions, just as with desire and so forth.
You ask, why are the eight parts established and not more or less.
The answer:
This question is not exhaustive, so it is set aside.
Moreover, because they counteract the eight wrong paths, the eight parts are taught.
Moreover, they are included in the three bodies.
Moreover, because they counteract the three thorns, three bonds, three fires, and three poisons, the eight parts are taught.
Furthermore, the Abhidharma-piá¹­aka says:
Because it can accomplish the mind with eight qualities, it is said to have eight parts.

Because of attaining right view, the mind is pure. Because of attaining right thought, the mind is fresh. Because of attaining right speech, the mind is level. Because of attaining right action, the mind is without regret. Because of attaining right livelihood, the mind is soft and smooth. Because of attaining right effort, the mind follows the teachings. Because of attaining right mindfulness, the mind abides peacefully. Because of attaining right concentration, the mind is unmoving.
You ask, why not take the other dharmas such as desire?
The answer:

Only the superior dharmas are taken, either taking the powerful function, or taking what can bear the burden, or both are included. Right speech, right action, and right livelihood are the factors of the srota-Äpanna, because faith is included in the three.
The srota-Äpanna is endowed with four knowledges and faith. Desire is precisely faith.
Furthermore, this faith is also included in right view. Because the srota-Äpanna person attains knowledge and faith.
Joy, serenity, and equanimity are included in right concentration.
Therefore, the eight factors encompass all the factors without exception.
You ask, How can one dharma be explained in three ways, such as being said to be the middle way that can extinguish good and evil practices and reach the end of suffering?
The answer:
Because of three superior matters.
For example, the sun can dispel darkness and is called light, it can distinguish day and night and is called the sun, and it can distinguish ká¹£aá¹‡as and so forth and is called the original time.

The noble path is also like this. It can detach from the two extremes and is called the middle way. It can eliminate black and white karma and is called the extinction of good and evil. It uproots the suffering of body and mind and is therefore said to reach the end of suffering through practice.
Or it eliminates the path of the three times, and is therefore said to reach the end of suffering through practice.
You ask, How is it said that right view is the first?
The answer:
Because it is the leader, like a king. As the sutra says:
Among all conditioned dharmas, prajÃ±Ä is the most supreme.

Furthermore, because it can create supreme merit. If wisdom is supreme, all merits are supreme. Like ÅšÄriputra, due to right view, he does not look at others' faces. Like the elder ÅšÅ«ra, due to right view, his mind is difficult to move. Like King AÅ›oka, due to right view, others cannot lead him. Like the elder Citra, he can uproot misfortune.
As the sÅ«tra says:
Because of the arising of illumination, ignorance is completely extinguished.
Therefore, right view is the first.
You ask, why is it said to be the forerunner?
The answer:
Because of attaining right view, the other factors attain supramundane, attain the uncontaminated, and attain the unique.
Or it is said that by the power of right view, the other factors attain the name of the path of liberation.
As the sÅ«tra says:
Bhiká¹£us!
For one with right view, the actions of body, speech, and mind attain lovable and excellent fruits. As the sÅ«tra explains in detail.
Therefore, right view is the forerunner.
You asked, What is the meaning of right view?
The answer:
It is called view because it is non-inverted realization and illumination, and it is the non-inverted realization and illumination of the true nature that one relies on.
Furthermore, suchness is called right, and seeing is called view. Because one observes the noble truths as they are, it is called right view.
Furthermore, right means that which is praiseworthy, and view means light. Because it is praiseworthy light, it is called right view.
As a sutra says:
Among all lights, this light is the most supreme, namely right view.
Furthermore, the wisdom that observes the realm of supreme virtues is called right view.
Why is it so?
This stage of right concentration is called right view, as the Sutra on the Parable of the Seeds says.
Furthermore, the NyÄyapraveÅ›a says:
Because the object is right, the cognition is right, not because the cognition is right, the object is right.
Because it is associated with the characteristics of conditioned and defiled existence, all are only suffering.
Definitely knowing this is called right view, as the Buddha said to MahÄkÄtyÄyana.
Also, the Abhidharma treatises say:
The antidote to ignorance, doubtful knowledge, and inverted knowledge, which can transcend suffering and so forth, this true knowledge is called right view.
You ask, if seeing does not exist, who is the seer?
The answer:
Many conditions gather together to form this seeing, there is no separate single thing that is the seer, it is like a flower or fruit.
Also, as a verse says:
There is seeing but no seer, what dharma is the seer?
Arising from the convergence of conditions, saying one sees form is false.
When this dharma gathers, there is seeing, but when it disperses there is no seer,
It is merely the product of conditions, like a scarecrow.
Dharmas arise from conditions, they cannot be said to belong to one, as the Buddha said to break the attachment of Guá¹‡a:
I do not say consciousness is the knower.
Why is it so?
This is because it is named based on its complete function.
You ask, How are the right views in the ten wholesome [courses of action] and the right views in the eightfold noble path different?
The answer is:
The worldly wisdom is in the ten wholesome [courses of action], and the true wisdom is in the eightfold noble path.
The right view that can lead to future lives, takes suffering as its fruit, and takes karma as its object, is in the ten wholesome dharmas.
The right view that can extinguish the three existences, takes nirvana as its fruit, and takes the truths as its object, is in the eightfold noble path.
You ask, If the truths are seen simultaneously by right view, there should be multiple objects;
if not, then it is not moment-to-moment cessation.
The answer is:
Because it can accomplish four things simultaneously, it is said to be simultaneous, not because the objects are different.
The *NyÄyapraveÅ›a says:
A practitioner of meditation, through the wisdom of the noble ones, can penetrate the pores and cut off all afflictions.
Also, another sÅ«tra says:
If one thoroughly observes the three feelings, all tasks are accomplished and there is nothing more to do.
Because of the common characteristics of the truths and the characteristic of non-self, therefore the four truths are universally contemplated at one time.
Just as in the contemplation in sequence, impermanence, suffering, and non-self are universally contemplated at one time regarding the truth of suffering.
You ask, if right view has already understood the truths, what is the use of the remaining factors?
The answer:
All the factors can eliminate their own opposites and each has its own function, just like vomiting and downward movement.
Furthermore, all the factors
are each foremost in their own affairs and together accomplish one thing.
It is like the parts of a cart and the cart itself.
Each has its own function and together they accomplish the function of transportation.
The factors of the path and the path itself are also like this.
You ask:
What is the meaning of right understanding?ğŸ”½The answer:
It is called right understanding because it is as if something that has never been conceived before is born today.
Furthermore, this is the equal Dharma, because of the arising of conceptualization and practice.
Furthermore, it is called right understanding because the essence, characteristics, realm, and result are mutually supportive.
Furthermore, it is like seeing and following the choice without abandoning, which is called right enlightenment, like a cow chewing cud.
You ask, how can the three dharmas form one?
The answer:
Because they have the same characteristic, like the other path factors.
Furthermore, it is because they are considered to be equal, like the factors of concentration.
Furthermore, because they take nirvana as their object, like the concentration of signlessness, therefore the three form one.

You ask, if one attains the destruction of the outflows by relying on the two concentrations, the right enlightenment is not complete, and there is a deficiency in the path factors, this meaning should be saved.
The answer:

If one cultivates the eightfold right path by relying on the two concentrations, there is only no initial and sustained thought of the first concentration factor, not no enlightenment in the path factor, like the first concentration and samÄdhi which have no initial and sustained thought.
Furthermore, it is said to have right enlightenment because of accomplishment, not because of being present, like the five faculties of one in training.
Furthermore, it is said to have right enlightenment because it can uproot the antidotes, like right speech.
You ask, what is the meaning of right speech?
The answer:
Permanently accepting a vow without breaking it is called right speech, as in the biography of Gautama.

You ask, what is the meaning of right action?
The answer:
The sutra says:
Being free from evil bodily actions is called right action.

This bodily action is not dissected, not flowing, not distributed, self-controlled, ungraspable, able to give rise to tranquility, this is called right action.

The answer:
If apart from this name, another name is not manifested, like the dharma realm, dharma entry, etc.

The meditation masters MaudgalyÄyana, Aniruddha, and others say that there is form as an object of concentration that is attained by the power of concentration. This form is not the domain of the eye faculty, so it is said to be invisible. It is unobstructing because it does not obstruct space.

Because it is the same as non-action, it still refutes your meaning.
You say:
Knowing that there is non-flowing form by speaking of it, there is an agent of non-action.
This is not so.
This form is also born from the power of concentration. Because concentration is non-flowing, form is also non-flowing.
Moreover, the masters explain that the form of an arhat is also non-flowing, because it is not the basis of the flows.
It is argued:
This meaning is not so.
As the sÅ«tra says:
What are the flowing dharmas?
They are all eyes, all forms, and so forth.
This form is not the antidote to the flows, so it is said to be flowing.
If so, this form is either flowing or non-flowing.
Answer:
If so, what is there?
The difficulty says:

The answer:
Like the characteristics of the contaminated and the uncontaminated, I do not know what characteristics are mixed.
Moreover, if the form aggregate is entirely contaminated, why does the sutra selectively explain it without saying it is universal?
The sutra says:
Contaminated form is that which is the basis for clinging, attachment, and concealment by the mind with grasping, and is therefore called contaminated form.

Just as you enjoy the offerings of the host, because the recipient benefits by their virtues, although the host is in a different mind, by the previously cultivated mind of giving perfuming and transforming the continuity, it gradually becomes superior. Question:

Because of repeatedly cultivating the intention of precepts and concentration, it increases and follows in the eyes.
Question:

What is the intention here? Therefore, it is the correct principle that the continuity becomes increasingly superior.

The Sutra school also makes this statement. If a person does it himself, when the matter is accomplished the continuity becomes increasingly superior, and it is called the path of action.
This meaning should be understood, because the effect is provisionally named after the cause.
This bodily and verbal matter is provisionally named after the body and speech. The meaning is also like this. It is like the non-teaching of the body and speech of the mind.

Based on the aggregates grasped by sentient beings, one obtains the sin of killing by the intention at three times, namely, killing for my sake, killing in the present, and killing after the fact.

You ask, what is vigor?
The answer:
Practicing everywhere, according to the distinctions of the stages, in order to attain various good dharmas, one exerts body and mind to bear the burden without abandoning it.
Furthermore, in order to eliminate evil dharmas and realize good dharmas, one always practices with vigor. This is called vigor.
Furthermore, practicing in this way without error, one exerts body and mind with effort. This is called vigor.
You ask, What are its characteristics, function, proximate cause, and meaning?
The answer:
Exerting body and mind is its characteristic, non-retrogression is its function, giving rise to the class of vigor is its proximate cause.

Vigor has the characteristic of courage, the function of non-sinking, the four right efforts as its proximate cause, and victorious practice as its meaning.
If a person is lazy, there is no victorious practice.
Furthermore, because it is difficult to overcome.
If a person has vigor, in the battle against afflictions they have the power to overcome what is difficult to overcome. If a lazy person, this is not the case.
Furthermore, this practice can disperse, eliminate, and abandon, which is the meaning of vigor.
You ask, if eliminating evil is good, then there are not two kinds of vigor;
if it is not good, then the truth of cessation is not good.
The answer:
Eliminating evil is only nothingness, but goodness is not like this, so vigor has two aspects.
Furthermore, eliminating evil is called true goodness, while the rest are the three kinds of goodness.
Why is this?
Because there are four kinds of goodness.

Separating from the stench of breaking precepts is called eliminating evil, while the arising of the fragrance of precepts is called generating good, just as heat is different from the arising of cold.
You ask, if one mind cultivates right effort and is complete, then there are not four right efforts;

The answer:
One mind can cultivate the four right efforts, just as one mind universally contemplates the four truths.
Why is this?
Because of this cultivation, unarisen evils do not arise, arisen evils do not remain, unarisen wholesome dharmas arise, and arisen wholesome dharmas remain firm.

Moreover, the VibhajyavÄdins say:

For this reason, right effort is one but has four functions.
Furthermore, some say:
The four right efforts arise in sequence, just like attaining concentration.
Why is this?

There is right effort that can only destroy the manifest afflictions, there is other right effort that can uproot the latent afflictions, there is right effort that can give rise to the unarisen faculties, and there is right effort that can make the arisen faculties firm.
Therefore, the cultivation of the factors of the path is not scattered cultivation, because there is right effort.
You ask, what is right mindfulness?
The answer:
Not forgetting the previously known object is called right mindfulness, just like grasping the characteristics.
As the sutra says:
Mindfulness is called mindfulness.
You ask, what are the characteristics, what is the function, what is the condition, and what is the meaning?
The answer:

The characteristic of later recollection of the object is the function of the mind and object not being separated. The six recollections are the conditions. The meaning of mindfulness is called self-recollection and reminding others, just like bodhi self-enlightenment and enlightening others.
Furthermore, the Abhidharma-piá¹­aka says:
The characteristic of the mind being clear and pure is non-forgetfulness. If lost, it returns to manifestation.
Furthermore, being able to guard the object is the basis of wisdom, therefore it is called mindfulness.

Furthermore, there are four kinds of mindfulness: 1. Following the names, phrases, and tastes grasped, 2. Being able to follow the meaning grasped, 3. Being able to follow the contemplated meaning, 4. Being able to follow the penetrated contemplated meaning.
The present treatise clarifies the fourth [type of memory].
You ask, If all conditioned dharmas do not abide for a moment, how can memory be established?
Why is this?
Because there is no such thing as one person seeing and another person remembering.
The answer is:
If the knower is different, memory is not established, like Zhang seeing and Wang remembering.
If the continuity of cognition is different, memory is also not established, like seeing an ox and not remembering a horse, etc.
If a single moment of cognition is also not established, because there is no subsequent cognition.
And these three meanings are called memory.
Another explanation: If there is no connection, then one person seeing and another person cannot remember, like this person seeing and that person not remembering.

If there is a connection through causes and conditions, then one person seeing and another person can remember, like the cognition of a young boy, a young man, and an old man, which can follow and arise.
Furthermore, it is like a seed, because it is not connected, wheat seeds do not produce barley sprouts.
If cause and effect are related but different, then seeds of grains and so forth would be able to give rise to sprouts, stems, joints, leaves, and so on.
If even a single moment is not established, then cause and effect are not established, just as a seed is always one and a sprout does not arise.
Because of the non-difference and non-singularity of the relationship, therefore a moment is established.
You ask, if all dharmas are mindfulness, and the faculty of mindfulness is mindfulness, then the meaning is not appropriate.
Answer:

The faculty of mindfulness discussed in this treatise is the four mindfulnesses. It is only because of the distinction of objects that the faculty is distinguished, just as the faculty of wisdom is distinguished by the amount of wisdom.
Furthermore, there are three kinds of mindfulness: First, the mindfulness of self-nature, which only gives rise to recollection, like a king.
Second, the mindfulness of combination, if a dharma can assist mindfulness it is also called mindfulness, like the king's ministers and aides are also called the king.
Third, the mindfulness of objects, because mindfulness arises by relying on this it is also called mindfulness, like the king's residence.
Therefore, the faculty of mindfulness is precisely the foundation of mindfulness, and there is no contradiction in meaning.

The answer:
Mindfulness is the foremost and supreme condition among guardians, so it is said to be the single guard, like the king being supreme.
As the sutra says:
All dharmas take mindfulness as the supreme condition, for the sake of guarding.
Moreover, a single mindfulness can protect all practices, so it is said to be the single guard.
As the sutra says:
This mindfulness is practiced everywhere.
Moreover, all mindfulness can guard the six faculties, like a gatekeeper.
Moreover, this mindfulness can record a single mind, like a person holding the mouth of a yin-yang tube with their hand.
Moreover, it is able to guard a single continuity, so it is called the single guard, like protecting a single child.
Moreover, the six faculties are bound to the pillar of a single mindfulness and do not scatter and abide in their own objects, like six beings bound to a single pillar together.
Therefore, the sutra says:
There is mindfulness that guards.
You ask, Why can one sometimes remember and sometimes not remember?
The answer:
There are three causes and conditions that can give rise to mindfulness. First, frequent practice, by frequently practicing body, speech, and mind, one sees as in a dream;
Second, characteristics, by remembering characteristics in accordance with or contrary to reality, one remembers the similar or dissimilar objective realm;
Third, clarity, by the mind being clear and pure, mindfulness arises, like seeing one's reflection in a clear vessel of water.
If one goes against these three, one cannot remember.
Moreover, at the time of death and at birth, one is oppressed by heavy suffering and loses one's original mindfulness, thus not remembering past lives.
Furthermore, there are six causes and conditions that can give rise to mindfulness.
As a verse says:
In accordance with, contrary to, and frequent practice, in one place, gathering together,
The power of concentration and the power of causes, these six are the causes of mindfulness.
In accordance with means, for example, seeing someone similar to one's child, one immediately remembers one's own child.
Contrary to means, due to touching heat, one remembers past coolness.
Repeated practice means that one naturally remembers things as one has become familiar with them.
Gathering in one place means that when a person sees a mango tree, they remember its sour taste.
The power of concentration means that a person who has attained the three insights remembers past lives.
The power of cause means that sages and those of great virtue remember their past lives.
You ask, what is samÄdhi?
The answer:
The sÅ«tras say that the mind dwelling in stillness is called samÄdhi.
Also, the Abhidharma-piá¹­aka says:
Being able to gather the dharmas and not be scattered is called samÄdhi.
Furthermore, the continuity of the mind cannot be moved by the evil winds of afflictions, like a lamp in a sealed room.

The characteristic is a single mind, the function is non-dispersal, the four samÄdhis are the conditions, and the meaning is to make the mind straight, like an arrow-maker straightening an arrow.

In this way, the continuity of the straightened mind is called samÄdhi.
As a verse says:
The beating and jumping of the mind is scattered and moving, difficult to guard and difficult to block,
The wise person makes it straight, like an arrow-maker straightening an arrow.
Furthermore, it can make the mind dwell in equality, like a charioteer taking a flat road to avoid dangerous and winding paths.
The practitioner is also like this. If they can place the mind in the gate of the realm of equality, and can block inequality and evil, it is called samÄdhi.
Furthermore, when the illness of the five hindrances is eliminated, it is like a person without illness, which is called samÄdhi.
You ask, If right concentration is concentration, then stream-enterers should have no desire or anger.
If not, then it contradicts reason.
The answer is, the concentration that is to be countered exists. Because of attaining the fruit, it is verified that they attain concentration, just like the five faculties.

Furthermore, because the mind is focused on concentration, it is like a bee that although bound in a filthy place, the mind still yearns for lotus flowers. Therefore, it is known that it always stays in the flowers.
The sages are also like this. Although they dwell in desires, their minds delight in tranquility. Therefore, it is known that they always stay in concentration.
Furthermore, it is like a stream-enterer. Although ignorance exists, their understanding is not lost.
Furthermore, it is like the Buddha, the BhagavÄn. Although he has thoughts and contemplations and does not emerge from scattered mind, he always stays in concentration.
The same is true for the fixed mind of the srota-Äpanna, so it does not contradict reason.
Question:
What is the sequence of the eight parts of the noble path?
Answer:
Because one contemplates the noble truths according to the principle of dependence, right view is established first.
Not abandoning the grasping and discernment of the contemplated dharmas, right thought is established next.
From this, right speech, right action, and right livelihood are established next.
In order to abandon and attain the contemplated dharmas, right effort is established next.
In order to never forget what has been abandoned and attained, right mindfulness is established next.
Because of not losing through mindfulness, the mind does not scatter and move in the seen objects, so right concentration is established next.
Furthermore, if the eight dharmas arise together, there is no sequence, but the sequential explanation is not without reason.
If a person wishes to give rise to nirvÄá¹‡a, they should first seek right view, just as a person who wishes to walk must have eyes.
Grasping and discerning according to the principle of what is seen, right thought is established next.
Speaking according to what has been discerned, right speech is established next.
Why is it so?
If there is speech, it is based on discursive thought.
Acting in accordance with words, next establish right action.
These two are pure, next establish right livelihood.
This person abides in precepts, if they arouse diligence, next establish right effort.
Because there is diligence, then mindfulness is not lost, next establish right mindfulness.
Because there is mindfulness, the mind is single and undistracted, next establish right concentration.
Furthermore, the Abhidharma-piá¹­aka says:
This practice takes wisdom as its root.
Why is it so?
The realm of the four truths is profound, not understood without wisdom, therefore right view is established first.
The mind touches this realm, next establish right thought.
By means of these two aspects, in the four truths one should make oneself understand, next establish right speech.
Due to the previous two aspects, acting in accordance with words, next establish right action.
Due to the previous two aspects, verbally speaking and bodily practicing the four truths, next establish right livelihood.
The body and mind diligently strive for progress in the truth, so next establish right effort.
By means of this right effort, the mind's function becomes clear and pure regarding the objects of the four truths, so next establish right mindfulness.
By means of this right mindfulness, the mind and all dharmas are forever unmoving regarding the objects of the four truths, so next establish right concentration.
Furthermore, due to right view, the practitioner does not fall into overestimation, because he can truly discriminate his own attainments.
Right thought gives rise to right speech, which can transmit to others what one has attained.
By means of this right speech, one can establish, refute, and decide, causing others to have faith in one's wisdom.
By having right action, one would rather give up one's life than violate what is not the Dharma, thus causing others to have faith in the precepts loved by the sages.
By seeking and using the four conditions according to the Dharma, right livelihood causes others to have faith in the noble lineage and contentment.
Furthermore, by right view, right thought, and right speech, one can roar like a lion.
Right action and right livelihood can manifest the meaning of what is said.
By right effort, one can attain what has not yet been attained and eliminate what has not yet been eliminated.
Because of right mindfulness, one does not forget the three characteristics when sinking or floating, so concentration is unobstructed.
Because of right concentration, one eliminates the obstacles to concentration and can induce the various virtues of the six supernormal powers, so one is subsequently liberated.
Furthermore, the Abhidharma-piá¹­aka says:
Because of right view, one speaks of the faculty of faith, the power of faith, and desire.
Why is this?
Because with wisdom, faith and desire are accomplished.
Because of vigor, one can include right effort, the faculties of vigor, effort, and the factors of enlightenment of vigor.

Because of right concentration, one includes the bases of spiritual success of the mind, the faculty of concentration, the power of concentration, and the factors of enlightenment of joy, serenity, equanimity, and concentration.
For this reason, one should know that the thirty-seven factors are included within the eightfold path.
Furthermore, right view and right mindfulness are parts of vipaÅ›yanÄ, because by them ignorance is eliminated, and the fruit is liberation by wisdom.
The remaining path factors belong to the category of Å›amatha, because by them desire is eliminated, and the fruit is liberation of the mind.
Therefore, the path is briefly said to have two parts: vipaÅ›yanÄ and Å›amatha.
Furthermore, the Abhidharma-piá¹­aka says:
The three of right speech, action, and livelihood are the aggregate of morality, because by having this morality, the root of anger and evil is eradicated.
The three of right view, effort, and concentration are the aggregate of concentration, because by this, the root of desire and lust is eradicated.
The two of right view and right mindfulness are the aggregate of wisdom, because by this, the root of ignorance is eradicated.
For this reason, the path has three parts.
Furthermore, the path has four: The path of preparation is that by which the unobstructed path arises. All that is prior to the unobstructed path is called preparation.
The two uninterrupted paths are so called because they are the direct antidotes that eliminate obstacles and because they do not obstruct afflictions.
The three liberated paths are so called because they liberate from the afflictions obstructed by the uninterrupted paths, and their initial arising is called liberation.
The four superior paths are so called because all the paths remaining after the liberated paths are called superior paths.
Question:
How are these four called paths?
Answer:
Because by this one advances to nirvana, it is called a path.
If so, how are liberation and superiority called paths?
Answer:
Because they are the types of paths, because they are superior, because they cause the previous to reach the subsequent, and because they can reach nirvana without remainder, they are called paths.

Furthermore, there are four kinds of paths: the path of slow wisdom in suffering, the path of quick wisdom in suffering, the path of slow wisdom in happiness, and the path of quick wisdom in happiness. The path of happiness is.
Because it relies on the four dhyanas in their entirety, because concentration and wisdom are balanced, and because it is effortless practice. For this reason, it is called the path of ease.

Apart from this, it is all called the path of difficulty, referring to reliance on the future dhyana, intermediate dhyana, and the three formless concentrations, because they are incomplete, because concentration and wisdom are unequal, and because there is effortful practice.

The future dhyana has little concentration and much wisdom, the three formless concentrations have much concentration and little wisdom, and the intermediate dhyana is incomplete, so both concentration and wisdom are little. For this reason, it is called the path of difficulty.
These two paths, if attained by one with the faculty of faith, are called slow progress, if attained by one with the faculty of wisdom, they are called quick progress.
This eightfold noble path, in terms of concentration and faculties, has four kinds of practice.
Next, the noble path is sometimes said to have thirty-seven factors of enlightenment.
What dharma is enlightenment?
Extinction knowledge and non-arising knowledge are called enlightenment.

The three kinds of people attain the three kinds of enlightenment, namely the enlightenment of the Å›rÄvakas, the enlightenment of the pratyekabuddhas, and the unsurpassed enlightenment, because they are able to extinguish ignorance without remainder.
This is called enlightenment because it is the realization of what is to be done, which is never to be done again, as it truly is.
The aids are the thirty-seven factors, which are called aids because they accompany the knowledge of elimination and the knowledge of non-arising.
They are called thirty-seven in name, but not in substance.
Now, what is discussed in the treatise has only ten substances, namely faith, zeal, mindfulness, concentration, wisdom, joy, tranquility, equanimity, morality, and enlightenment.
The Abhidharma masters say:
The substances are eleven, which is to open morality into two, namely bodily and verbal.
There are also Abhidharma masters who say:
The substances are thirteen, which is to add desire and thought.
The sÅ«tra says that all attained dharmas are aids to enlightenment, but since these ten are superior, they are mentioned specifically.

As for the thirty-seven, they are the four establishments of mindfulness, four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five powers, eightfold noble path, and seven factors of awakening.
Question:
Where are these seven categories of aids to awakening established?
Answer:
There are four stages in general: the stage of initial practice, the stage of penetrating understanding, the stage of seeing, and the stage of cultivation.
Question:
What is the sequence?
Answer:

This practitioner of contemplation, already abiding in precepts, is able to discern the faults of saá¹ƒsÄra and the merits of nirvÄá¹‡a. Apart from the four truths, there is no other expedient that can understand these faults and merits. In order to gather the scattered mind of many objects and make it abide in one place, in order to give rise to antidotes and subdue the four inverted views, and cause the mind to enter the contemplation of the four truths in accordance with principle, therefore, one first contemplates the four establishments of mindfulness.

Having already discerned through the four establishments of mindfulness the dharmas that can be accepted and rejected, in order to accept the good and reject the evil, one next practices the right efforts.

The four right efforts are accomplished based on the four foundations of mindfulness. Due to the right efforts, the hindrances of afflictions are already purified, and the auxiliary dharmas are established. Since the mind abides as one wishes, the four bases of supernatural power are established next.
By the power of this concentration, the mind has supremacy in the realm of no doubt.
By this faith, the mind has supremacy in the realm of no laziness.

The good mind obtained by this right effort has assistance and no hindrances. The mind has supremacy in the realm of no forgetting. By this mindfulness, it is included in one object. The mind has supremacy in the realm of no distraction.

By this concentration, the mind has supremacy in the realm of true observation. Because of the supremacy of the inherent nature, the mind has supremacy in the stage of no retrogression. Because of no retrogression, the mind has supremacy in the stage of penetrating insight. Therefore, the five faculties are established next.

Because these five faculties grow to the highest degree, because lower defilements cannot destroy them, because other worldly dharmas cannot surpass them, because they are the immediate condition for the pure mind, and because one does not regress from the holy stage, for this reason the five powers are established next.

Having already seen the gains and losses of this and that, having already attained the true path, having already attained certainty, having already attained the eye, having already attained the feet, one emerges from worldly practices by means of the five powers, and therefore the eightfold noble path is established next.

Having already destroyed the defilements seen by the truths by means of the eightfold noble path, one attains the knowledge of destruction and the knowledge of non-arising, and therefore this path is transformed and called the seven factors of enlightenment.
Therefore the thirty-seven are established in sequence.

The four establishments of mindfulness are the initial stage of practice, which is the stage of liberation. The four right efforts are called the stage of forbearance. The four bases of supernatural power are called the stage of characteristics. The five faculties are called the stage of the foremost dharma. These four are collectively called the stage of certainty.

The eightfold noble path is called the stage of seeing, the seven factors of enlightenment are called the stage of cultivation, the knowledge of extinction and the knowledge of non-arising are called the ultimate stage, because they are fruits and not causes, they are not established as paths.
Furthermore, this path is sometimes called the wheel of BrahmÄ.
The wheel of BrahmÄ is so called because it is turned by the Buddha, the World-Honored One, and his disciples.
This noble path has six meanings, which are likened to a wheel.
First, rapid progress, that is, progressing through the three realms and the four truths in either one thought, twelve thoughts, or fifteen thoughts, and thus it is called rapid.
Second, abandoning this and reaching that, that is, abandoning the mundane and reaching the supramundane, and so forth.
Third, ascending and descending, that is, being in either the acceptance of dharmas or the acceptance of subsequent knowledge, and so forth.
Fourth, from this to that, that is, from the understanding transmitted by teachers to the understanding transmitted by disciples.
Fifth, because it resembles the hub, spokes, and rim.
The precepts have three parts as the hub, right view, right thought, right effort, and right mindfulness as the spokes, and right concentration as the rim.
The six noble kings' wheels, which can subdue the unyielding and protect the yielded.
By the unobstructed path, one can subdue, and by the path of liberation, one can guard. For this reason, it is called the wheel of BrahmÄ.
Furthermore, this eightfold noble path has five parts in right view.
The precepts have six kinds, namely the three karmas and their inhibitions.
Right effort has nine parts.ğŸ”½Right mindfulness has eight parts.
Right concentration also has eight parts.
This noble path, if explained in detail, has thirty-seven parts, if explained in the middle, it has eight parts, if explained in brief, it has either three parts or two parts.
